title: Special member state territories and the European Union
text:
The special territories of the European Union are 32 territories of <a href="Member%20state%20of%20the%20European%20Union">EU member states</a> which, for historical, geographical, or political reasons, enjoy special status within or outside the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>.
The special territories divide themselves in three categories: 9 Outermost Regions (OMR) that form part of the European Union, though they benefit from <a href="derogation">derogation</a>s from some EU laws due to their geographical remoteness from mainland Europe; 13 Overseas Countries and Territories (OCT) that do not form part of the European Union, though they cooperate with the EU via the <a href="Overseas%20Countries%20and%20Territories%20Association">Overseas Countries and Territories Association</a>; and 10 special cases that form part of the European Union (with the exception of the <a href="Faroe%20Islands">Faroe Islands</a>), though EU laws make "<a href="ad%20hoc">ad hoc</a>" provisions.
The Outermost Regions were recognised at the signing of the <a href="Maastricht%20Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a> in 1992, and confirmed by the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> in 2007. The <a href="Treaty%20on%20the%20Functioning%20of%20the%20European%20Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a> states that both primary and secondary <a href="European%20Union%20law">European Union law</a> applies automatically to the outermost regions, with possible derogations due to the particularities of these territories. The Overseas Countries and Territories are recognised by the Article 198 of the <a href="Treaty%20on%20the%20Functioning%20of%20the%20European%20Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a> which allows them to opt into EU provisions on the freedom of movement for workers and freedom of establishment, and invites them to join the <a href="Overseas%20Countries%20and%20Territories%20Association">Overseas Countries and Territories Association</a> (OCTA) in order to improve cooperation with the European Union. The status of an uninhabited territory, <a href="Clipperton%20Island">Clipperton</a>, remains unclear since it is not explicitly mentioned in primary <a href="EU%20law">EU law</a> and has a "<a href="sui%20generis">sui generis</a>" status at the national level.
Collectively, the special territories encompass a population of some 6.1 million people and a land area of about 2,733,792 square kilometres (1,055,500 sq mi). Around 80 percent of this area is represented by <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>. The largest region by population, the <a href="Canary%20Islands">Canary Islands</a>, accounts for more than a third of the total population of the special territories. The smallest by land area is the island of <a href="Saba">Saba</a> in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> (13 km2 or 5 sq mi). The <a href="French%20Southern%20and%20Antarctic%20Lands">French Southern and Antarctic Lands</a> is the only special territory without a permanent population.
Outermost regions.
The Outermost regions (OMR) are territories forming part of a member state of the European Union but situated a significant distance from <a href="continental%20Europe">mainland Europe</a>. Due to this situation, they have <a href="derogation">derogation</a> from some EU policies despite being part of the European Union.
According to the <a href="Treaty%20on%20the%20Functioning%20of%20the%20European%20Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a>, both primary and secondary <a href="European%20Union%20law">European Union law</a> applies automatically to these territories, with possible derogations to take account of their "structural social and economic situation (...) which is compounded by their remoteness, insularity, small size, difficult topography and climate, economic dependence on a few products, the permanence and combination of which severely restrain their development". All form part of the <a href="European%20Union%20Customs%20Union">European Union customs area</a>, however some fall outside of the <a href="Schengen%20Area">Schengen Area</a> and the <a href="European%20Union%20Value%20Added%20Tax%20Area">European Union Value Added Tax Area</a>.
Seven outermost regions were recognised at the signing of the <a href="Maastricht%20Treaty">Maastricht Treaty</a> in 1992. The <a href="Treaty%20of%20Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> included two additional territories (<a href="Saint%20Barth%C3%A9lemy">Saint Barthélemy</a> and <a href="Collectivity%20of%20Saint%20Martin">Saint Martin</a>) in 2007. Saint Barthélemy changed its status from OMR to OCT with effect from 1 January 2012. <a href="Mayotte">Mayotte</a>, which was an OCT, joined the EU as an OMR with effect from 1 January 2014.<ref name="CD 2013/61/EU"></ref>
The 9 Outermost Regions of the European Union are:
Autonomous Regions of Portugal.
<a href="Azores">Azores</a> and <a href="Madeira">Madeira</a> are two groups of Portuguese islands in the Atlantic. Azores and Madeira are integral parts of the Portuguese Republic, but both have the special status as <a href="Autonomous%20Regions%20of%20Portugal">Autonomous Regions</a>, with a degree of self-governance. Some derogations from the application of EU law apply in regards to taxation, fishing and transportation. Their <a href="Value-added%20tax">VAT</a> is lower than the rest of Portugal, but they are not outside the <a href="European%20Union%20value%20added%20tax">EU VAT Area</a>.
Canary Islands.
The <a href="Canary%20Islands">Canary Islands</a> are a <a href="Spain">Spanish</a> <a href="archipelago">archipelago</a> off the African coast which form one of the 17 <a href="autonomous%20communities%20of%20Spain">autonomous communities of Spain</a>–the country's principal first-level administrative division. They are outside the <a href="EU%20VAT%20Area">EU VAT Area</a>. The Canary Islands are the most populous and economically strongest territory of all the outermost regions in the European Union. The outermost regions office for support and information is located in these islands, in the city of <a href="Las%20Palmas">Las Palmas</a> on the island of <a href="Gran%20Canaria">Gran Canaria</a>.
French overseas regions.
<a href="French%20Guiana">French Guiana</a>, <a href="Guadeloupe">Guadeloupe</a>, <a href="Martinique">Martinique</a>, <a href="Mayotte">Mayotte</a>, and <a href="R%C3%A9union">Réunion</a> are five French <a href="overseas%20department%20and%20region">overseas regions</a> (which are also overseas departments) which under French law are, for the most part, treated as integral parts of the Republic. The <a href="euro">euro</a> is legal tender; however, they are outside the <a href="Schengen%20Area">Schengen Area</a> and the EU VAT Area.
Mayotte is the newest of the five overseas departments, having changed from an overseas collectivity with OCT status on 31 March 2011. It became an outermost region, and thus part of the EU, on 1 January 2014.<ref name="CD 2013/61/EU2"></ref>
Collectivity of Saint Martin.
<a href="Collectivity%20of%20Saint%20Martin">Saint Martin</a> is the only <a href="overseas%20collectivity">overseas collectivity</a> of France with the status of being an outermost region of the EU. As with the French overseas departments, the <a href="euro">euro</a> is legal tender in Saint Martin, and it is outside the Schengen Area and the EU VAT Area.
On 22 February 2007, Saint Martin and <a href="Saint%20Barth%C3%A9lemy">Saint Barthélemy</a> were broken away from the French overseas department of <a href="Guadeloupe">Guadeloupe</a> to form new overseas collectivities. As a consequence their EU status was unclear for a time. While a report issued by the French parliament suggested that the islands remained within the EU as outermost regions, European Commission documents listed them as being outside the European Community. The legal status of the islands was clarified on the coming into force of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a>, which listed them as an outermost region. However, Saint Barthélemy ceased being an outermost region and left the EU, to become an OCT, on 1 January 2012.
Overseas countries and territories.
The overseas countries and territories (OCT) are dependent territories that have a special relationship with one of the member states of the EU. Their status is described in the <a href="Treaty%20on%20the%20Functioning%20of%20the%20European%20Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a>, and they are not part of the EU or the <a href="European%20Single%20Market">European Single Market</a>. The <a href="Overseas%20Countries%20and%20Territories%20Association">Overseas Countries and Territories Association</a> was created to improve economic development and cooperation between the OCTs and the EU, and includes most OCTs except three territories which do not have a permanent local population.
The OCTs have been explicitly invited by the EU treaty to join the <a href="Overseas%20Countries%20and%20Territories%20Association">EU-OCT Association</a> (OCTA). They were listed in the Article 198 of the <a href="Treaty%20on%20the%20Functioning%20of%20the%20European%20Union">Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union</a>, which aside from inviting them to join OCTA, also provided them the opportunity to opt into EU provisions on the freedom of movement for workers and freedom of establishment. Yet, the freedom of establishment is limited by Article 203 TFEU and the respective Council Decision on OCTs. Its Article 51(1)(a) prescribes only that "the Union shall accord to natural and legal persons of the OCTs a treatment no less favourable than the most favourable treatment applicable to like natural and legal persons of any third country with whom the Union concludes or has concluded an economic integration agreement." Again this can be, according to Article 51(2)(b) limited. The obligations provided for in paragraph 1 of this Article shall not apply to treatment granted under measures providing for recognition of qualifications, licences or prudential measures in accordance with Article VII of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) or the GATS Annex on Financial Services.
The OCTs are not subject to the EU's common external customs tariffs but may claim customs on goods imported from the EU on a non-discriminatory basis. They are not part of the EU and the <a href="EU%20acquis">EU acquis</a> does not apply to them, though those joining OCTA are required to respect the detailed rules and procedures outlined by this association agreement (Council Decision 2013/755/EU). OCTA members are entitled to ask for EU financial support.
When the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Rome">Rome Treaty</a> was signed in March 1957, a total of 15 OCTs existed: <a href="French%20West%20Africa">French West Africa</a>, <a href="French%20Equatorial%20Africa">French Equatorial Africa</a>, <a href="Saint%20Pierre%20and%20Miquelon">Saint Pierre and Miquelon</a>, <a href="Comoros%20Archipelago">Comoros Archipelago</a>, <a href="French%20Madagascar">French Madagascar</a>, <a href="French%20Somaliland">French Somaliland</a>, <a href="New%20Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>, <a href="French%20Settlements%20in%20Oceania">French Polynesia</a>, <a href="French%20Southern%20and%20Antarctic%20Lands">French Southern and Antarctic Lands</a>, <a href="French%20Togoland">French Togoland</a>, <a href="French%20Cameroons">French Cameroons</a>, <a href="Belgian%20Congo">Belgian Congo</a>, <a href="Ruanda-Urundi">Ruanda-Urundi</a>, <a href="Trust%20Territory%20of%20Somalia">Trust Territory of Somalia</a>, <a href="Netherlands%20New%20Guinea">Netherlands New Guinea</a>. The list was since then revised multiple times, and comprised—as noted by the Lisbon Treaty—25 OCTs in 2007. One of the French territories subsequently switched status from OMR to OCT (<a href="Saint%20Barth%C3%A9lemy">Saint Barthélemy</a>), while another French territory switched from OCT to OMR (<a href="Mayotte">Mayotte</a>). As of July 2014, there are still 13 OCTs (six with France, six with the Netherlands and one with Denmark) of which all have joined OCTA.
The 13 Overseas Countries and Territories of the European Union are:
Overseas Countries and Territories Association.
The <a href="Overseas%20Countries%20and%20Territories%20Association">Overseas Countries and Territories Association</a> (OCTA) is an organisation founded on 17 November 2000 and headquartered in <a href="Brussels">Brussels</a>. All OCTs have joined OCTA as of February 2020. Its purpose is to improve economic development in overseas countries and territories, as well as cooperation with the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>. On 25 June 2008, a Cooperation Treaty between the EU and OCTA was signed in Brussels. The current chairman is the Premier of <a href="Cura%C3%A7ao">Curaçao</a>, <a href="Eugene%20Rhuggenaath">Eugene Rhuggenaath</a>.
French overseas territories.
The <a href="French%20Southern%20and%20Antarctic%20Lands">French Southern and Antarctic Lands</a> (which also include the French <a href="Scattered%20Islands%20in%20the%20Indian%20Ocean">Scattered Islands in the Indian Ocean</a>, and the French claim of <a href="Ad%C3%A9lie%20Land">Adélie Land</a> in <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>) is a French Overseas Territory but has no permanent population. It has "sui generis" status within France.
<a href="Saint%20Pierre%20and%20Miquelon">Saint Pierre and Miquelon</a>, <a href="Saint%20Barth%C3%A9lemy">Saint Barthélemy</a>, <a href="French%20Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>, and <a href="Wallis%20and%20Futuna">Wallis and Futuna</a> are <a href="overseas%20collectivity">overseas collectivities</a> (formerly referred to as overseas territories) of France, while <a href="New%20Caledonia">New Caledonia</a> is a ""<a href="sui%20generis">sui generis</a>" collectivity". Saint Barthélemy and Saint Pierre and Miquelon use the <a href="euro">euro</a>, while New Caledonia, French Polynesia and Wallis and Futuna use the <a href="CFP%20Franc">CFP Franc</a>, a currency which is tied to the euro and guaranteed by France. Natives of the collectivities are <a href="European%20citizens">European citizens</a> owing to their French citizenship and elections to the European Parliament are held in the collectivities.
On 22 February 2007, <a href="Saint%20Barth%C3%A9lemy">Saint Barthélemy</a> and <a href="Collectivity%20of%20Saint%20Martin">Saint Martin</a> were separated from the French overseas department of <a href="Guadeloupe">Guadeloupe</a> to form new <a href="Overseas%20collectivity">overseas collectivities</a>. As a consequence, their EU status was unclear for a time. While a report issued by the French parliament suggested that the islands remained within the EU as outermost regions, European Commission documents listed them as being outside the European Community. The legal status of the islands was clarified on the coming into force of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Lisbon">Lisbon Treaty</a> which listed them as outermost regions. However, Saint Barthélemy ceased being an outermost region and left the EU, to become an OCT, on 1 January 2012. The change was made to facilitate trade with countries outside the EU, notably the United States, and was made possible by a provision of the Lisbon Treaty which allows the <a href="European%20Council">European Council</a> to change the EU status of a Danish, Dutch, or French territory on the initiative of the member state concerned.
Dutch overseas territories.
Six territories of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20the%20Netherlands">Netherlands</a>—all of which are Caribbean islands—have OCT status. As such, they benefit from being able to have their own export and import policy to and from the EU, while still having access to various EU funds (such as the <a href="European%20Development%20Fund">European Development Fund</a>). The inhabitants of the islands are EU citizens owing to their Dutch citizenship, with the right to vote in elections to the European Parliament. Initially they did not have voting rights for such elections, but the <a href="European%20Court%20of%20Justice">European Court of Justice</a> granted them such rights, when they ruled their exclusion from the franchise was contrary to EU law, as all other Dutch citizens resident outside the EU did have the right to vote. None of the islands use the euro as their currency. The <a href="United%20States%20dollar">US dollar</a> is used on Bonaire, Sint Eustatius and Saba, while Curaçao and Sint Maarten utilize their own shared currency the <a href="Netherlands%20Antillean%20guilder">Antillean guilder</a>, and finally the currency of Aruba is the <a href="Aruban%20florin">Aruban florin</a>.
<a href="Aruba">Aruba</a>, <a href="Cura%C3%A7ao">Curaçao</a>, and <a href="Sint%20Maarten">Sint Maarten</a> are classified as "countries" under Dutch law, and have considerable internal autonomy. In June 2008, the Dutch government published a report on the projected effect on the islands were they to join the EU as outermost regions. It concluded that the choice would be for the islands themselves to weigh up the advantages and disadvantages of becoming part of the EU as outermost regions, and that nothing would be done absent the islands specifically requesting it.
<a href="Bonaire">Bonaire</a>, <a href="Sint%20Eustatius">Sint Eustatius</a>, and <a href="Saba">Saba</a> (collectively called <a href="Caribbean%20Netherlands">Caribbean Netherlands</a>) are "special municipalities" of the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands proper</a>. Their current OCT status, and the prospect of advancing their status to become part of the EU as new OMRs (outermost regions), was reviewed by the Dutch parliament in 2015, as part of the planned review of the Dutch law (WOLBES and FINBES) concerning the quality of their recently implemented new public administration bodies. In October 2015, the review concluded the present legal structures for governance and integration with European Netherlands was not working well within the framework of WolBES, but no recommendations were made in regards of whether a switch from OCT to OMR status would help improve this situation.
The islands inherited their OCT status from the <a href="Netherlands%20Antilles">Netherlands Antilles</a> which was <a href="Dissolution%20of%20the%20Netherlands%20Antilles">dissolved in 2010</a>. The <a href="Netherlands%20Antilles">Netherlands Antilles</a> were initially specifically excluded from all association with the EEC by reason of a protocol attached to the Treaty of Rome, allowing the Netherlands to ratify on behalf of the Netherlands in Europe and <a href="Netherlands%20New%20Guinea">Netherlands New Guinea</a> only, which it subsequently did. Following the entry into force of the <a href="Convention%20on%20the%20association%20of%20the%20Netherlands%20Antilles%20with%20the%20European%20Economic%20Community">Convention on the association of the Netherlands Antilles with the European Economic Community</a> on 1 October 1964, however, the Netherlands Antilles became OCTs.
Greenland.
<a href="Greenland">Greenland</a> joined the then <a href="European%20Community">European Community</a> in 1973 as a <a href="County%20of%20Greenland">county</a> along with Denmark, but after gaining autonomy with the introduction of <a href="home%20rule">home rule</a> within the <a href="Denmark">Kingdom of Denmark</a>, Greenland voted to leave in <a href="1982%20Greenlandic%20European%20Communities%20membership%20referendum">1982</a> and left in <a href="Withdrawal%20of%20Greenland%20from%20the%20European%20Communities">1985</a>, to become an OCT. The main reason for leaving is disagreements about the <a href="Common%20Fisheries%20Policy">Common Fisheries Policy</a> (CFP) and to regain control of Greenlandic fish resources to subsequently remain outside EU waters. Greenlandic nationals (OCT-nationals) are, nonetheless, <a href="European%20Union%20citizen">EU citizens</a> due to Greenland's associated relationship with the EU within the meaning of EU treaties as well as holding <a href="Danish%20nationality%20law">Danish nationality</a>.
The EU–Greenland relationship is a comprehensive partnership, which is complementary to the OCT association arrangements under "Council Decision 2013/755/EU"; based specifically on "Council Decision 2014/137 of 14 March 2014" (outlining the relations) and the Fisheries Partnership Agreement of 30 July 2006.
Special cases.
While the outermost regions and the overseas countries and territories fall into structured categories to which common mechanisms apply, this is not true of all the special territories. 10 member state territories have "<a href="ad%20hoc">ad hoc</a>" arrangements in their relationship with the EU. In those special cases, <a href="European%20Union%20Value%20Added%20Tax%20Area">VAT rules</a> do not apply and they may also be exempt from <a href="European%20Union%20Customs%20Union">customs</a> or <a href="excise">excise</a> rules.
Åland.
<a href="%C3%85land">Åland</a>, an autonomous archipelago belonging to Finland, but with partial autonomy, located between Sweden and Finland, with a Swedish-speaking population, joined the EU along with <a href="Finland">Finland</a> in 1995. The islands had a separate referendum on accession and like the Finnish mainland voted in favour.
EU law, including the fundamental <a href="Internal%20Market">four freedoms</a>, applies to Åland. However, there are some derogations due to the islands' special status. Åland is outside the VAT area and is exempt from common rules in relation to <a href="turnover%20tax">turnover tax</a>es, excise duties and indirect taxation.
In addition, to protect the local economy, the treaty of accession allows for a concept of "hembygdsrätt/kotiseutuoikeus" (regional citizenship). Consequently, there are restrictions on the holding of property and real estate, the right of establishment for business purposes and limitations on who can provide services in Åland, for people not holding this status. The status may be obtained by any Finnish citizen legally resident in Åland for 5 years who can demonstrate an adequate knowledge of the Swedish language.
Büsingen am Hochrhein.
The <a href="Germany">German</a> village of <a href="B%C3%BCsingen%20am%20Hochrhein">Büsingen am Hochrhein</a> is an <a href="exclave">exclave</a> entirely surrounded by <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, and as such is, for practical purposes, in a <a href="customs%20union">customs union</a> with the latter non-EU country. The euro is legal tender, though the <a href="Swiss%20franc">Swiss franc</a> is preferred. Büsingen is excluded from the EU customs union and the EU VAT area. Swiss VAT generally applies. Büsingen was also outside of the Schengen area until Switzerland joined on 12 December 2008.
Campione d'Italia and Livigno.
The <a href="Italy">Italian</a> <a href="exclave">exclave</a> village of <a href="Campione%20d%27Italia">Campione d'Italia</a> is enclaved by <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>'s <a href="Ticino">Ticino</a> <a href="Cantons%20of%20Switzerland">canton</a> as well as <a href="Lake%20Lugano">Lake Lugano (or Ceresio)</a>, and is a "<a href="comune">comune</a>" in the <a href="Province%20of%20Como">Province of Como</a>, whilst <a href="Livigno">Livigno</a>, a small and remote mountain resort town, is a "comune" in the <a href="Province%20of%20Sondrio">Province of Sondrio</a>. Both "comuni" are part of the <a href="Lombardy">Lombardy</a> <a href="Regions%20of%20Italy">region</a>. Although part of the EU, Livigno is excluded from the customs union and VAT area, with Livigno's tax status dating back to Napoleonic times. Campione is excluded from the EU VAT area. It was excluded from the EU customs area until the end of 2019.<ref name="2019/474"></ref> Shops and restaurants in Campione accept payments in both euros and Swiss francs, and prices are displayed in both euros and Swiss francs.
Ceuta and Melilla.
<a href="Ceuta">Ceuta</a> and <a href="Melilla">Melilla</a> are two Spanish cities on the North African coast. They are part of the EU but they are excluded from the <a href="Common%20Agricultural%20Policy">common agricultural</a> and fisheries policies. They are also outside the customs union and VAT area, but no customs are levied on goods exported from the Union into either Ceuta and Melilla, and certain goods originating in Ceuta and Melilla are exempt from customs charges.
While nominally part of the <a href="Schengen%20Area">Schengen Area</a> (Schengen visas are valid), Spain performs identity checks on all sea and air passengers leaving the enclaves for elsewhere in the Schengen Area.
Cyprus.
When the <a href="Republic%20of%20Cyprus">Republic of Cyprus</a> became part of the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> on 1 May 2004, the northern third of the island was outside of the effective control of its government due to the <a href="Turkish%20invasion%20of%20Cyprus">Turkish invasion of Cyprus</a>, a United Nations buffer zone of varying width separated the two parts, and a further 3% of the island was taken up by <a href="UK%20sovereign%20base">UK sovereign base</a>s (under British sovereignty since the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Establishment">Treaty of Establishment</a> in 1960). Two <a href="treaty">protocol</a>s to the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Accession%202003">Treaty of Accession 2003</a>—numbers 3 and 10, known as the "Sovereign Base Areas Protocol" and the "Cyprus Protocol" respectively – reflect this complex situation.
EU law only applies fully to the part of the island that is effectively controlled by the government of the Republic of Cyprus. EU law is suspended in the northern third of the island (the <a href="Turkish%20Republic%20of%20Northern%20Cyprus">Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus</a>, whose independence is recognised only by <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>) by article 1(1) of the Cyprus Protocol. If the island is reunified, the <a href="Council%20of%20the%20European%20Union">Council of the European Union</a> will repeal the suspension by a decision. Four months after such a decision has been adopted, new elections to the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a> will be held on the island to elect Cypriot representatives from the whole of the island.
<a href="Cypriot%20nationality%20law">Cypriot nationality law</a> applies to the entire island and is accordingly available to the inhabitants of Northern Cyprus and the British sovereign base areas on the same basis as to those born in the area controlled by the Republic of Cyprus. Citizens of the Republic of Cyprus living in <a href="Northern%20Cyprus">Northern Cyprus</a> are EU citizens and are nominally entitled to vote in elections to the European Parliament; however, elections to that Parliament are not organised in Northern Cyprus as it is governed de facto by a separate state, albeit a state recognized only by Turkey.
Akrotiri and Dhekelia.
The United Kingdom has two sovereign base areas on Cyprus, namely <a href="Akrotiri%20and%20Dhekelia">Akrotiri and Dhekelia</a>. Unlike other British overseas territories, their inhabitants (who are entitled to <a href="British%20Overseas%20Territories%20Citizen">British Overseas Territories Citizen</a>ship) have never been entitled to <a href="British%20citizen">British citizen</a>ship.
Prior to Cypriot accession to the EU in 2004, although the United Kingdom was an EU member at the time, EU law did not apply to the sovereign base areas. This position was changed by the Cypriot accession treaty so that EU law, while still not applying in principle, applied to the extent necessary to implement a protocol attached to that treaty. This protocol applied EU law relating to the <a href="Common%20Agricultural%20Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a>, customs, indirect taxation, social policy and justice and home affairs to the sovereign base areas. The sovereign base areas' authorities also made provision for the unilateral application of directly applicable EU law. The UK also agreed in the Protocol to keep enough control of the external (i.e. off-island and northern Cyprus) borders of the base areas to ensure that the border between the sovereign base areas and the Republic of Cyprus could remain fully open and would not have to be policed as an external EU border. Consequently, the sovereign base areas would have become a "<a href="de%20facto">de facto</a>" part of the Schengen Area if and when Cyprus implemented it. The base areas are already "de facto" members of the <a href="eurozone">eurozone</a> due to their previous use of the <a href="Cypriot%20pound">Cypriot pound</a> and their adoption of the <a href="euro">euro</a> as legal tender from 2008.
Because Cypriot nationality law extends to Cypriots in the sovereign base areas, Cypriot residents, as citizens of the Republic of Cyprus, are entitled to EU citizenship. Just under half of the population of the sovereign base areas are Cypriots, the rest are British military personnel, support staff and their dependants. In a declaration attached to the <a href="London-Z%C3%BCrich%20Agreements">Treaty of Establishment of the Republic of Cyprus</a> of 1960, the British government undertook not to allow new settlement of people in the sovereign base areas other than for temporary purposes.
Under a protocol to the <a href="Brexit%20withdrawal%20agreement">Brexit withdrawal agreement</a>, certain provisions of EU law on agriculture, customs, indirect taxation, social security and border control continue to apply to the sovereign base areas.
United Nations buffer zone.
The <a href="United%20Nations%20Buffer%20Zone%20in%20Cyprus">United Nations buffer zone</a> between north and south Cyprus ranges in width from a few metres in central <a href="Nicosia">Nicosia</a> to several kilometres in the countryside. While it is nominally under the sovereignty of the Republic of Cyprus, it is effectively administered by the <a href="United%20Nations%20Peacekeeping%20Force%20in%20Cyprus">United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus</a> (UNFICYP). The population of the zone is 8,686 (as of October 2007), and one of the mandates of UNFICYP is "to encourage the fullest possible resumption of normal civilian activity in the buffer zone". Inhabited villages located in the buffer zone are legally administered by the Republic of Cyprus but policed by UN peacekeepers.Article 2.1 of the Cyprus Protocol allows the European Council to determine to what extent the provisions of EU law apply in the buffer zone.
Faroe Islands.
The <a href="Faroe%20Islands">Faroe Islands</a> are not part of the EU, and they have not been part of the EU since Denmark joined the community in 1973. Danish citizens residing on the islands are not considered citizens of a member state within the meaning of the treaties or, consequently, citizens of the European Union. However, Faroese people may become EU citizens by changing their residence to the Danish mainland.
The Faroe Islands are not part of the Schengen Area, and Schengen visas are not valid. However, the islands are part of the <a href="Nordic%20Passport%20Union">Nordic Passport Union</a> and the Schengen Agreement provides that travellers passing between the islands and the Schengen Area are not to be treated as passing the external frontier of the Area. This means that there is no formal passport control, but an identity check at check-in for air or boat travel to the islands where Nordic citizens on intra-Nordic travel need no passport, only showing the ticket plus identity card.
Heligoland.
<a href="Heligoland">Heligoland</a> is an archipelago of Germany situated in the <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a> off the German north-western coast. It is part of the EU, but is excluded from the customs union and the VAT area.
Mount Athos.
<a href="Mount%20Athos">Mount Athos</a> is an autonomous monastic region of <a href="Greece">Greece</a>. Greece's EU accession treaty provides that Mount Athos maintains its centuries-old special legal status, guaranteed by article 105 of the <a href="Constitution%20of%20Greece">Greek Constitution</a>. It is part of the customs union but outside the VAT area. Notwithstanding that a special permit is required to enter the peninsula and that there is a prohibition on the admittance of women, it is part of the <a href="Schengen%20Area">Schengen Area</a>. The monastery has certain rights to house monks from countries outside the EU. A declaration attached to Greece's accession treaty to the <a href="Schengen%20Agreement">Schengen Agreement</a> states that Mount Athos's "special status" should be taken into account in the application of the Schengen rules.
Areas of <a href="extraterritoriality">extraterritoriality</a>.
The Saimaa Canal and Värska–Ulitina road are two of several distinct travel arrangements that exist or existed because of changes in borders over the course of the 20th century, where transport routes and installations ended up on the wrong side of the border. Some have become superfluous thanks to the Schengen Agreement. These listed examples pass the external EU border.
Saimaa Canal.
Finland <a href="Leased%20territory">leases</a> the -long Russian part of the <a href="Saimaa%20Canal">Saimaa Canal</a> from <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and is granted <a href="extraterritoriality">extraterritoriality</a> rights. The area is not part of the EU, it is a special part of Russia. Under the treaty signed by Finnish and Russian governments, Russian law is in force with a few exceptions concerning maritime rules and the employment of canal staff which fall under Finnish jurisdiction. There are also special rules concerning vessels travelling to Finland via the canal. <a href="Visa%20policy%20of%20Russia">Russian visas</a> are not required for just passing through the canal, but a passport is needed and it is checked at the border. Euros are accepted for the canal fees. Prior to the 50-year lease renewal coming into effect in February 2012, the <a href="Maly%20Vysotsky%20Island">Maly Vysotsky Island</a> had also been leased and managed by Finland. Since then it has been fully managed by Russian authorities, and is no longer part of the concession territory.
Värska–Ulitina road.
The road from <a href="V%C3%A4rska%20Parish">Värska</a> to <a href="Ulitina">Ulitina</a> in <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a>, traditionally the only road to the Ulitina area, goes through Russian territory for one kilometre (0.6 mi) of its length, an area called <a href="Saatse%20Boot">Saatse Boot</a>. This road has no border control, but there is no connection to any other road in Russia. It is not permissible to stop or walk along the road. This area is a part of <a href="Russia">Russia</a> but is also a de facto part of the Schengen area.
Switzerland.
Some roads and railways along the border of Switzerland allow transit between two Swiss places though neighbour countries without customs controls (and before 2008 passport controls), or between the border and international airports. See <a href="Privileged%20transit%20traffic%23Switzerland">Privileged transit traffic#Switzerland</a>.

Non-EU countries and territories with partial EU integration.
Some European countries are strongly connected to the European Union, through the <a href="European%20Economic%20Area">European Economic Area</a> or similar agreements. These countries are <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a>, <a href="Liechtenstein">Liechtenstein</a>, <a href="Norway">Norway</a> and <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, the member states of the <a href="European%20Free%20Trade%20Association">European Free Trade Association</a> (EFTA). They are inside the single market (with exceptions) and the Schengen area, but outside the Eurozone, customs territory, and VAT area. <a href="Norway">Norway</a> and <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> have special areas.
Under the <a href="Northern%20Ireland%20Protocol">Northern Ireland Protocol</a> of the <a href="Brexit%20withdrawal%20agreement">Brexit withdrawal agreement</a>, <a href="Northern%20Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> remains <a href="de%20facto">de facto</a> part of the <a href="European%20Single%20Market">European Single Market</a> and the <a href="European%20Union%20Customs%20Union">European Union Customs Union</a> for the purposes of goods only, in order to prevent the creation of a customs border on the island of <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a>.
In addition, the <a href="British%20Overseas%20Territories">British territory</a> of <a href="Akrotiri%20and%20Dhekelia">Akrotiri and Dhekelia</a> is partially integrated with <a href="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> in the areas of agriculture, customs, indirect taxation, social security and border control.
